item.title: American Airlines grounds all US flights due to 'technical issue' ahead of Christmas - Deccan Herald
item.description:
American Airlines Grounds All US Flights Due to Technical Issues Ahead of Christmas

Published: 24 December 2024, 12:48 IST

American Airlines has grounded all its flights in the US due to technical issues, disrupting the holiday travel of thousands of passengers.

  • All US flights were halted due to unspecified technical issues.
  • Numerous passengers reported being stuck on the runway and returned to the gate.
  • American Airlines has not provided a formal statement or estimated time for resolution.
  • The airline operates thousands of flights per day, serving over 350 destinations globally.
  • This grounding follows a previous global tech outage affecting airlines months earlier.
Two years ago, Southwest Airlines experienced a meltdown during the holidays leading to 16,900 flight cancellations affecting 2 million passengers.

This incident has significant implications for holiday travel plans as the airline works to resolve the technical issues.

item.title: American Airlines, World's Largest, Grounds All US Flights On Christmas Eve - NDTV
item.description:
American Airlines Grounds All US Flights on Christmas Eve Due to Technical Glitch

Date: December 24, 2024 Source: Reuters

On Christmas Eve, American Airlines, the world's largest airline carrier, grounded all its flights in the United States due to a technical glitch. This disruption occurs during one of the busiest travel times of the year.

  • American Airlines faced a technical glitch leading to the grounding of all US flights.
  • The airline informed passengers of the situation and promised updates every 15 minutes.
  • Many passengers expressed frustration on social media about the cancellations and inconveniences.
  • Shares of American Airlines fell by 3.8% before market opening.
  • This incident follows a notable Microsoft outage that impacted various industries globally.
“Our teams are working to resolve the issue as quickly as possible, and we apologize to our customers for the inconvenience.” - American Airlines

This incident highlights the vulnerabilities in airline operations during peak travel seasons, raising questions about the reliability of technological systems in critical infrastructure.

item.title: New Batch Of Sukhoi Su-57 Stealth Fighters Delivered To Russian MoD; Rostec CEO Calls It “King Of The Sky” - EurAsian Times
item.description:
New Batch Of Sukhoi Su-57 Stealth Fighters Delivered To Russian MoD; Rostec CEO Calls It "King Of The Sky"

Publication Date: Not specified Source: EurAsian Times

The United Aircraft Corporation (UAC) has delivered a new batch of Su-57 Felon and Su-34 Fullback combat aircraft to the Russian Ministry of Defense, marking a significant enhancement of Russia's aerial capabilities.

  • Rostec CEO Sergei Chemezov described the Su-57 as the "king of the sky" and praised its advanced capabilities.
  • The Su-57 is designed for various combat missions and can target air, ground, and sea threats in challenging conditions.
  • The Su-34 is a capable fighter-bomber that can engage long-distance targets despite enemy jamming efforts.
  • This delivery indicates a steady expansion of Russia’s aerial capabilities amidst ongoing challenges.
  • Russia has faced significant aircraft losses since the invasion of Ukraine, which has affected production and delivery rates.
  • Western sanctions have hindered sourcing of vital components, pushing Russia to rely on alternative suppliers.
“The Su-57 and Su-34 are among the best in their class. They address critical tasks while showcasing superior maneuverability and combat performance.” - Vadim Badekha, head of the UAC

The ongoing production and delivery of these aircraft reflect Russia's commitment to enhancing its military capabilities despite external challenges and setbacks.

item.title: Who is Amelia Carter? Is she really the victim of the NYC subway horror? - The Times of India
item.description: No summary available for this article. Click the link to read more.

item.title: Elon Musk slams controversy over Trump aide Sriram Krishnan’s immigration views: ‘Fixed pie fallacy’ - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Elon Musk Responds to Immigration Views of Trump Aide Sriram Krishnan

Date: Dec 24, 2024 | Source: Hindustan Times

Elon Musk criticized the controversy around Sriram Krishnan's immigration views, describing opposing opinions as a “fixed pie” fallacy during his induction as a senior White House Policy Advisor.

  • Musk took to X to share his thoughts on the debates surrounding green card caps.
  • Krisnan's stance aims to remove country caps for green cards, which he believes would enhance skilled immigration.
  • David Sacks clarified that Krishnan supports skills-based criteria for green cards, not an unlimited immigration program.
  • Several tech leaders, including Joe Lonsdale, defended Krishnan's appointment and views.
“The ‘fixed pie’ fallacy is at the heart of much wrong-headed economic thinking. There is essentially infinite potential for job and company creation.” - Elon Musk

This discourse highlights important themes around immigration reform, economic policy, and national leadership in AI, particularly in the context of Trump's administration.

item.title: Eiffel Tower catches fire, thousands evacuated - Firstpost
item.description:
Eiffel Tower Catches Fire, Thousands Evacuated

Date: Tuesday, Source: French Police

The Eiffel Tower caught fire, leading to the evacuation of approximately 12,000 visitors as firefighters struggle to contain the blaze in the elevator shaft.

  • Flames were observed in the elevator shaft between the first and second floors.
  • About 12,000 visitors were evacuated from the tower.
  • Firefighters are on the scene but facing difficulties due to the location of the fire.
  • This is a developing story.
This is a developing story.

Authorities are working diligently to address the fire and ensure the safety of everyone involved.

item.title: ‘I am not a Pakistani’, clarifies YouTuber Zara Dar, who quit PhD for OnlyFans - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Zara Dar addresses misinformation about her that had spread since she posted a video stating that she was quitting her PhD for OnlyFans

Date: Dec 24, 2024 Source: Hindustan Times

YouTuber Zara Dar, known for quitting her PhD studies to pursue a career on OnlyFans, clarified misinformation regarding her heritage, asserting that she is American and not Pakistani.

  • Dropped out of her PhD to focus on being a full-time content creator on OnlyFans.
  • Clarified that she is of mixed background: American, Persian, Southern European, Middle Eastern, and Indian.
  • Addressed misconceptions regarding her name causing confusion with another influencer.
  • Stated she continues to share educational content on YouTube related to her engineering background.
“With all due respect, I am not Pakistani. I am American, born and raised.”

The event has sparked conversations about identity and the impact of social media on personal narratives.

item.title: South Korean opposition postpones decision to impeach acting president - CNA
item.description:
South Korean Opposition Delays Impeachment Decision for Acting President Han Duck-soo

Publication Date: December 24, 2023

Source: Channel News Asia

The South Korean opposition has chosen to postpone a decision to impeach acting president Han Duck-soo, initially set for Christmas Eve, until December 26, allowing for further evaluation of the situation.

  • The opposition Democratic Party decided not to present an impeachment motion on December 24 as intended.
  • This decision followed Han’s refusal to enact special Bills aimed at investigating the impeached former president Yoon Suk Yeol.
  • Park Chan-dae, the party’s floor leader, expressed a desire to consider public sentiments before proceeding.
  • Yoon Suk Yeol faces allegations tied to an interim martial law declaration and corruption claims against his wife, Kim Keon Hee.
  • The impeachment process requires six favorable votes from the nine-member Constitutional Court.
“We have decided to exercise patience, taking into account the sentiments of the people, and wait until the 26th to determine whether our demands are met.” - Park Chan-dae

In summary, the Democratic Party's strategic delay reflects a careful approach to a highly contentious political situation in South Korea.

item.title: Mob justice replaces extrajudicial killings in Yunus-led interim govt in Bangladesh, stability hangs in balance - The Hindu
item.description:
Mob Justice Sur replaces Extrajudicial Killings in Yunus-led Interim Govt in Bangladesh, Stability Hangs in Balance

Date: December 24, 2024 Source: The Hindu

In recent months, Bangladesh has experienced a surge in mob justice with incidents escalating after the fall of Sheikh Hasina's government. The interim government, led by Dr. Muhammad Yunus, has been unable to restore law and order amidst increasing violence.

  • Abdul Hai Kanu, a 78-year-old freedom fighter, was publicly humiliated and assaulted by a mob on December 22, highlighting the rise in mob justice.
  • Over 82 people were killed due to mob incidents in just four months under the interim government.
  • Despite police presence, fear among officers leads to reluctance in intervention during violent incidents.
  • The country has seen a sharp rise in robbery and muggings, with at least 10 killed in Dhaka alone during this period.
  • Human rights groups have reported a significant increase in fabricated legal cases during this time.
“We are deeply concerned about mob justice. Police are not intervening, leading people to believe they can act without police interference.” - Advocate Saidur Rahman

While mob violence has surged, there has been a noted decline in extrajudicial killings, previously rampant under the ousted regime. However, as political instability continues, the question of law and order remains critical in Bangladesh.

item.title: 'Like a battlefield': 12 killed in blast at Turkey's explosives plant - The Times of India
item.description:
12 Killed in Explosion at Turkish Explosives Plant

Publication Date: October 2023 Source: Times of India

An explosion at an explosives plant in Turkey has resulted in the tragic deaths of 12 individuals. The incident emphasizes the risks associated with the production of explosives.

  • The explosion occurred at a facility known for producing military-grade munitions.
  • Rescue operations are currently underway, with emergency services deployed to the site.
  • The cause of the explosion is under investigation, with authorities looking into safety protocols.
“Such incidents are a stark reminder of the dangers in handling explosive materials.”

In conclusion, this incident highlights the need for stringent safety measures in industries dealing with hazardous materials to prevent further tragedies.

item.title: 'Okay to get paid less than Americans': Entrepreneur justifies lower wages to Indian workers for overseas - The Times of India
item.description:
Entrepreneur Defends Paying Indian Workers Lower Wages for Overseas Work

Publication Date: Available upon access

Source: Available upon access

In a controversial statement, an entrepreneur has justified the practice of paying Indian workers less than their American counterparts for work targeting international markets.

  • The entrepreneur argues it aligns with local economic standards.
  • This stance has sparked debate on fair wages and globalization.
  • Supporters claim it allows for competitive pricing, while critics argue it perpetuates inequality.
"It is okay to pay less than Americans because of the different cost of living and local market standards."

This statement adds to the ongoing discussions about wage disparities in global job markets.

item.title: PhD aspirant to OnlyFans model: Who is Zara Dar, influencer whose career choice sparked a debate? - Deccan Herald
item.description:
Zara Dar: From PhD Aspirant to OnlyFans Model

Date: 24 December 2024 IST

Zara Dar, a former PhD student from Texas, has made headlines by leaving her academic path to pursue a full-time career as an OnlyFans model, igniting discussions about modern career choices in the digital age.

  • Dar is known for her YouTube channel where she simplifies complex scientific theories.
  • She expressed that her decision to leave PhD studies feels like a gamble but offers greater personal freedom.
  • Dar aims to combine science with personal content on her OnlyFans, differentiating her from typical adult content creators.
  • She plans to use her earnings to support STEM projects and scholarships, emphasizing her commitment to education and empowerment.
“It was a tough decision to leave something I’ve worked so hard for, but ultimately, this path allows me to be more creative and in control of my future.” - Zara Dar

In conclusion, Zara Dar's shift to content creation represents a modern trend of professionals redefining career success beyond traditional academic paths.

item.title: 'House of horrors': US gay couple get 100 years in prison for raping adopted sons - The Times of India
item.description:
US Couple Sentenced to 100 Years for Raping Adopted Sons

Date: Date not provided Source: Source not provided

The tragic case of a gay couple in the United States who received 100 years in prison for the heinous crime of raping their adopted sons sheds light on child abuse issues in adoptive homes.

  • The couple's actions have shocked the local community and raised awareness about the plight of abused children.
  • Authorities emphasized the importance of monitoring adoptive parents to prevent such horrific occurrences in the future.
  • This case has also sparked conversations about child welfare policies and the adoption process.
“Justice has been served, but we need to do more to protect vulnerable children.” - Local advocacy group

This case serves as a grim reminder of the need for better regulations and oversight in child adoption processes.

item.title: Bangladesh shown its place by US ahead of Jaishankar's visit, Yunus schooled for..., Dhaka assures to… - India.com
item.description:
Bangladesh shown its place by US ahead of Jaishankar's visit, Yunus schooled for...

Publication Date: Not specified Source: India.com

New Delhi: The global recognition of India as a significant power is growing, especially under Prime Minister Narendra Modi. The United States has expressed concerns about violence against Hindus in Bangladesh, culminating in a recent phone call with Mohammad Yunus, the Chief Advisor of Bangladesh.

  • Jaishankar embarks on a 6-day trip to the US.
  • The US contacted Bangladesh to address concerns over human rights, specifically regarding violence against Hindus.
  • Yunus assured compliance with human rights commitments during his conversation with US National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan.
“Bangladesh expressed its commitment to respecting and defending the human rights of all individuals.”

With Bangladesh under scrutiny, Jaishankar's visit aims to reinforce India's position regarding minority rights in the region.

item.title: France President Macron names 2024's fourth government amid political turmoil - The Times of India
item.description:
France President Macron names 2024's fourth government amid political turmoil

Publication Date: [Insert Date Here]

Source: [Insert Source Here]

In the midst of ongoing political challenges, President Emmanuel Macron has announced his fourth government for the year 2024, aiming to address pressing issues facing France.

  • This new government is a response to the current political turmoil.
  • Macron aims to implement reforms to stabilize the political landscape.
  • The government reshuffle comes amid rising public dissent.
“This government will focus on listening to the people's concerns and addressing their needs,” said Macron during the announcement.

The newly formed government reflects Macron's commitment to navigate through the political challenges and reform France's governance for the betterment of its citizens.

item.title: Kathy Hochul faces calls to resign after Guatemalan migrant burns woman alive, Elon Musk says ‘she should be recalled’ - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Kathy Hochul Faces Pressure to Resign Following Tragic Subway Incident

Publication Date: Dec 24, 2024 Source: Hindustan Times

New York Governor Kathy Hochul is facing calls to resign after a tragic incident involving the death of a woman at the hands of an illegal Guatemalan immigrant aboard a subway train.

  • Hochul shared a post on social media about subway safety improvements on the same day of the incident.
  • Elon Musk and Rep. Ritchie Torres criticized her for the timing of her post.
  • The suspect, Sebastian Zapeta-Calil, 33, has been charged with murder and arson.
  • Local politicians and residents are calling for Hochul's resignation, citing her insensitivity.
“You may mean well, but being governor is just not for you.” - Dov Hikind

The incident has sparked widespread outrage and discussions on public safety in New York, raising questions about Hochul's leadership.

item.title: Gay couple gets 100 years in jail for raping adopted sons, recording porn in 'house of horrors' - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Gay Couple Sentenced to 100 Years for Raping, Abusing Adopted Sons in 'House of Horrors'

Date: Dec 24, 2024 - Source: Hindustan Times

A US court sentenced a gay couple to 100 years in prison without parole for raping two special needs sons they adopted, sexually abusing them, recording pedophilic pornography, and offering the kids to their friends.

  1. The couple forced their adopted sons, now 12 and 10 years old, to have sex with them.
  2. They recorded the abuse and shared it with their friends.
  3. The abuse came to light after police discovered sexual abuse material uploaded to a Google account.
  4. The couple pleaded guilty to charges including aggravated sodomy, sexual exploitation of children, and child molestation.
"These two Defendants truly created a house of horrors and put their extremely dark desires above everything and everyone else." - Randy McGinley, District Attorney

The couple was arrested in 2022, and their victims have shown remarkable resilience throughout the case.

item.title: 'Will behead…': Israel's ominous warning to ‘Houthi terrorist organisation’ - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Israel Warns Houthi Group, Admits to Hamas Leader's Killing

Date: Dec 24, 2024

Israeli Defence Minister Israel Katz admitted on Monday that Israel killed Hamas leader Ismail Haniyeh in Iran in July. In a warning to the Houthi group, Katz stated that Israel had 'defeated' other adversaries and would 'behead their leaders' just as they did with Haniyeh.

Katz's statement comes amid ongoing conflicts in the region, with Israel pounding Gaza and targeting Hezbollah in Lebanon. Iran-backed Houthis in Yemen have been attacking commercial shipping in the Red Sea, claiming to express solidarity with Palestinians in Gaza.

With inputs from Reuters

Read the full article here.

item.title: Founder says it’s okay to pay Indian workers less than Americans. Controversial post sparks debate - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Founder says it’s okay to pay Indian workers less than Americans. Controversial post sparks debate

December 24, 2024 - Hindustan Times

Franco Pereyra, the COO of staffing agency Near, has ignited controversy with his remarks on paying overseas workers less than Americans, citing lower living costs as justification.

  • Pereyra's comments on LinkedIn suggest it's acceptable for global talent to earn less due to lower living costs and limited opportunities abroad.
  • He acknowledged that while some exploitation occurs, it is not inherently wrong to pay overseas workers less.
  • His statements have been widely shared on social media, leading to a heated debate about labor practices and pay equity.
  • Workers from countries like India and the Philippines are highlighted as particularly vulnerable to being treated as disposable labor.
  • Pereyra warns that both workers and companies suffer from high turnover rates resulting from exploitative labor practices.
“A lot of people get upset and say workers in Latin America, India, and the Philippines are being exploited... But paying less for overseas work is not inherently wrong.” - Franco Pereyra

The debate generated by Pereyra’s comments reflects broader issues in the global workforce regarding fair compensation and working conditions.

item.title: Capable Of Striking Indian Bases In Andamans! Meet Pakistan’s Nuclear Missiles That Have Rattled The US & Alarmed New Delhi - EurAsian Times
item.description:
Capable Of Striking Indian Bases In Andamans! Meet Pakistan’s Nuclear Missiles That Have Rattled The US & Alarmed New Delhi

Publication Date: December 19, 2024 Source: EurAsian Times

The article discusses the recent sanctions imposed by the United States on entities involved with Pakistan's long-range ballistic missile program, highlighting concerns about Pakistan's capability to strike targets well beyond South Asia, particularly the US.

  • The US imposed new sanctions on December 18, targeting four entities related to Pakistan’s missile program.
  • The sanctions come amidst fears that Pakistan might eventually develop the capability to reach targets outside of South Asia.
  • Pakistan's Shaheen-III and Ababeel missiles are highlighted as significant developments in its nuclear arsenal.
  • Concerns have been raised about Pakistan's collaboration with foreign firms to enhance its missile capabilities.
  • Experts argue that Pakistan's missile developments are primarily aimed at countering India.
“If these trend lines continue, Pakistan will have the capability to strike targets well beyond South Asia, including the United States, raising real questions about Pakistan’s intentions.” - Johnathan Finer

The ongoing development of Pakistan's missile capabilities has prompted serious discussions regarding its implications for regional and global security, particularly concerning US interests.

item.title: Enter the talks - DAWN.com
item.description:
Enter the Talks: PTI and Government Negotiations in Pakistan

Published on: December 24th, 2024 | Source: Dawn

The PTI party is signaling its willingness to engage in talks with the government amidst a backdrop of internal tensions and public unrest. While leaders within PTI advocate for discussions, the government shows mixed reactions, hinting at ongoing complexities in negotiations.

  • PTI's enthusiasm for dialogue contrasts with Imran Khan's unpredictable stance.
  • The government has formed its own committee for talks, characterized as a broad coalition.
  • Concerns over the absence of a clear agenda on both sides, potentially leading to ineffective discussions.
  • Historical precedent suggests that real decision-making occurs away from public scrutiny.
  • Despite skepticism, there are indications that the establishment may support dialogue efforts.
The real decision-making in Pakistan takes place behind closed doors; always has and always will.

In conclusion, while the call for negotiations is timely, the efficacy and outcomes of these talks remain uncertain given historical contexts and vested interests.

item.title: Trudeau’s time’s up? Dozens of Canadian Liberal MPs revolt after Freeland’s exit - WION
item.description:
Trudeau Faces Revolt from Liberal MPs After Freeland's Departure

Date: December 2023

Source: WION

Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau is facing increasing pressure from within his own party following the surprising resignation of Deputy Prime Minister Chrystia Freeland. Reports indicate that a significant number of Ontario MPs are now calling for his removal.

  • Support for Trudeau has declined rapidly since Freeland's unexpected exit.
  • At least 51 Ontario MPs convened virtually to discuss showing Trudeau the door.
  • Freeland's resignation is seen as a catalyst for rising discontent among Liberal MPs.
  • 21 MPs have publicly urged Trudeau to step down within just a week.
  • Quebec MP Anthony Housefather suggests that many MPs believe Trudeau should resign.
"The vast majority of fellow MPs believe Trudeau should resign, whether they’ve gone public or not." - Anthony Housefather

The turmoil within the Liberal party could lead to significant political consequences as the next elections approach, and calls for new leadership increase.

item.title: Mossad agents claim Hezbollah had ‘exploding pagers’ for decades - DAWN.com
item.description:
Mossad agents claim Hezbollah had ‘exploding pagers’ for decades

Published on: December 24th, 2024 | Source: Dawn

Two former Israeli intelligence agents disclosed that Hezbollah unknowingly utilized Israeli-made walkie-talkies and pagers rigged with explosives, resulting in a catastrophic surprise attack in September 2024. The agents detailed how Mossad deceived Hezbollah into purchasing over 16,000 devices.

  • On September 17, 2024, thousands of pagers exploded simultaneously across Lebanon, causing widespread panic and casualties.
  • Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu later acknowledged Israel's involvement in the attacks.
  • Mossad concealed explosives within the devices, ensuring they inflicted minimal collateral damage.
  • The operation aimed to create fake companies to sell the modified devices without linking them back to Israel.
  • Hezbollah purchased 5,000 booby-trapped pagers, which were detonated remotely when requisite.
“We have an incredible array of possibilities of creating foreign companies that have no way being traced back to Israel,” said one agent.

This revelation underscores the lengths to which intelligence agencies might go in modern warfare, blending technology and deception.

item.title: A history of the Panama Canal - and why Trump can't take it back on his own - The Times of India
item.description:
A History of the Panama Canal - and Why Trump Can't Take It Back on His Own

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Not specified

The article discusses the historical context of the Panama Canal and explores the complexities surrounding any potential reclamation of control by former President Trump.

  • The Panama Canal has a significant historical and geopolitical impact.
  • Ownership and control issues are multifaceted and cannot be resolved unilaterally.
  • The article examines past treaties and current implications regarding the canal.
“The Canal is not just a physical passage; it represents decades of negotiation and international relations.”

In conclusion, the article emphasizes that any attempts to reclaim control over the Panama Canal would require extensive diplomatic efforts and cannot be done through simple political declarations.

item.title: Bystanders accused of looking on and doing nothing as Guatemalan migrant set woman on fire, ‘Nobody came to her aid’ - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Bystanders accused of looking on and doing nothing as Guatemalan migrant set woman on fire, ‘Nobody came to her aid’

Date: Dec 24, 2024
Source: Hindustan Times

The incident occurred on December 22, where a Guatemalan migrant allegedly set a woman on fire aboard a Brooklyn subway train while bystanders did nothing to help.

  • Footage shows at least three people present, with one filming the event while a police officer stood by.
  • Suspect Sebastian Zapeta-Calil, 33, was arrested and charged with first- and second-degree murder and arson.
  • Community activists are expressing outrage at the bystanders' inaction, citing fear of involvement in legal issues.
  • Calls for accountability from the transit agency have been made following this incident.
  • Curtis Sliwa, a community leader, highlighted the chilling effect of recent legal cases on potential rescuers.
“Nobody came to her aid,” said Guardian Angels founder Curtis Sliwa.

In light of this event, discussions surrounding public safety and community responsibility are underway, with significant concerns about criminal activity and the role of bystanders.
